stages.description: Using place value counters (100,000; 10,000; 1,000; 100; 10; 1) on a six-column place value mat to build, partition and compare numbers up to 1,000,000
resources: place value mat (HTh, TTh, Th, H, T, O)
stages.example_activity: Build 304,056 with place value counters: 3 hundred-thousands, 0 ten-thousands, 4 thousands, 0 hundreds, 5 tens, 6 ones. What is the value of the 3? (300,000). Partition: 300,000 + 4,000 + 50 + 6. Use arrow cards to layer the number. Compare 304,056 and 340,056 — which counter column differs?
stages.transition_cue: Child reads, writes and partitions six-digit numbers without counters, explaining the value of each digit including zero placeholders

stages.description: Using place value charts, number lines to 1,000,000, and Gattegno charts to represent, compare and order large numbers on paper
stages.example_activity: Write 725,403 in a place value chart. Mark it on a number line between 700,000 and 800,000. Use a Gattegno chart to build numbers by pointing: 700,000 + 25,000 + 400 + 3. Order five six-digit numbers from smallest to largest, comparing column by column.
stages.transition_cue: Child reads and compares any number up to 1,000,000 without visual aids, articulating the column-by-column comparison

stages.description: Working with numbers to 1,000,000 mentally: identifying digit values, partitioning flexibly, comparing, ordering, and reading/writing in words
stages.example_activity: What is the value of the 8 in 382,510? Write 'four hundred and nine thousand and twelve' in numerals. Is 599,999 closer to 500,000 or 600,000? What number is 10,000 more than 395,000?
stages.transition_cue: Child works with any number to 1,000,000 fluently, partitioning flexibly and comparing instantly

stages.description: Using number lines marked in 10,000s and 100,000s to physically locate numbers and identify which bounding multiple they are nearer to
stages.example_activity: Place 347,500 on a number line marked in 100,000s: it falls between 300,000 and 400,000. Is it closer to 300,000 or 400,000? (300,000 — the midpoint is 350,000 and 347,500 < 350,000.) Now round to the nearest 10,000: between 340,000 and 350,000, closer to 350,000.
stages.transition_cue: Child identifies the bounding multiples and chooses the nearer one without a number line, correctly applying the '5 rounds up' convention

stages.description: Drawing number line segments to show the rounding process, marking midpoints and decisions, and recording rounding to different degrees of accuracy
stages.example_activity: Draw a number line from 250,000 to 350,000 in steps of 10,000. Mark 287,500. Midpoint between 280,000 and 290,000 is 285,000. Since 287,500 > 285,000, round up to 290,000. Record: 287,500 ≈ 290,000 (nearest 10,000), ≈ 300,000 (nearest 100,000).
stages.transition_cue: Child rounds any number to any power of 10 by identifying the key digit, without drawing a number line

stages.description: Rounding any number up to 1,000,000 to any power of 10 using the digit-checking rule, and applying rounding to estimate calculations with large numbers
stages.example_activity: Round 847,356 to the nearest 1,000; 10,000; 100,000. Estimate 472,381 + 289,654 by rounding each to the nearest 100,000. Does 95,000 round to 100,000 or 90,000 to the nearest 10,000?
stages.transition_cue: Child rounds any large number to any degree of accuracy within 3 seconds and uses rounding to estimate calculations routinely

stages.description: Using counters to build arrays for each number 2-30, identifying which numbers can only make a 1-by-n array (primes) and which can form multiple arrays (composites), following the Sieve of Eratosthenes with a hundred square
stages.example_activity: Try to arrange 7 counters into a rectangle: only 1 × 7 works. Try 12: 1×12, 2×6, 3×4 — multiple rectangles. Numbers with only one rectangle (besides 1×n) are prime. On the hundred square, cross out multiples of 2 (not 2), then multiples of 3 (not 3), then 5, then 7. The remaining numbers are prime.
stages.transition_cue: Child explains that a prime number has exactly two factors (1 and itself) and can identify primes up to 20 without the sieve

stages.description: Recording factor pairs to test for primeness, drawing factor trees, and using the completed Sieve of Eratosthenes as a reference to identify primes on paper
stages.example_activity: Is 37 prime? Check: 37 ÷ 2? No. 37 ÷ 3? No. 37 ÷ 5? No. √37 ≈ 6, so only need to check up to 6. 37 is prime. Draw a factor tree for 60: 60 = 2 × 30 = 2 × 2 × 15 = 2 × 2 × 3 × 5. List the prime factors.
stages.transition_cue: Child tests any number up to 100 for primeness using systematic factor checking and identifies prime factors without the sieve

stages.description: Identifying prime and composite numbers mentally, recalling primes up to at least 19, and explaining why 1 is not prime and why 2 is the only even prime
stages.example_activity: Is 51 prime? (No: 51 = 3 × 17.) Is 29 prime? (Yes.) List all primes less than 30. Why is 1 not prime? (It has only one factor, not two.) Why is 2 the only even prime?
stages.transition_cue: Child identifies primes and composites up to 100 confidently, explains the definition, and uses prime factorisation to decompose numbers

stages.description: Building square arrays from tiles (3×3=9, 4×4=16, 5×5=25...) and cubic structures from linking cubes (2×2×2=8, 3×3×3=27) to see square and cube numbers as physical shapes
stages.example_activity: Build a 5×5 square from tiles: count 25 tiles. So 5² = 25. Build a 3×3×3 cube from linking cubes: count 27 cubes. So 3³ = 27. List all square numbers by building arrays: 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36, 49, 64, 81, 100, 121, 144. Which numbers are both square and cube?
stages.transition_cue: Child states all square numbers up to 144 and the first five cube numbers from memory, connecting them to area and volume

stages.description: Drawing square arrays on squared paper, recording the square and cube number sequences, and using the n² and n³ notation
stages.example_activity: Draw square arrays for 1² through 12² on squared paper. Record: 1²=1, 2²=4, 3²=9... 12²=144. Draw cubes on isometric paper for 1³, 2³, 3³, 4³, 5³. Record using notation: 7² = 49, 4³ = 64. Is 64 a square number too? (Yes: 8² = 64.)
stages.transition_cue: Child uses the n² and n³ notation correctly, identifies whether a given number is square or cube, and generates these sequences without drawing

stages.description: Recalling square and cube numbers instantly, using the notation, and applying them in calculations and reasoning
stages.example_activity: What is 9²? What is 4³? Is 49 a square number? What is √81? If the area of a square is 144 cm², what is the side length? If the volume of a cube is 125 cm³, what is the edge length?
stages.transition_cue: Child answers any square/cube number question within 3 seconds and connects them to area and volume problems

stages.description: Building arrays to find all factor pairs, using counters on Venn diagram sorting hoops to identify common factors, and laying out multiples with Cuisenaire rods to find common multiples
stages.example_activity: Find all factor pairs of 36 using arrays: 1×36, 2×18, 3×12, 4×9, 6×6. Find factors of 24: 1×24, 2×12, 3×8, 4×6. Put factors of 36 in one hoop, factors of 24 in another. Overlap: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 12. HCF = 12. Lay out multiples of 4 and 6 with rods: LCM = 12.
stages.transition_cue: Child lists all factor pairs systematically and identifies common factors, HCF, and LCM without arrays or hoops

stages.description: Drawing Venn diagrams of factor sets, recording factor trees, listing multiples to find LCM, and connecting HCF and LCM to fraction operations
stages.example_activity: Draw a Venn diagram: factors of 30 and factors of 42. Common factors: 1, 2, 3, 6. HCF = 6. So 30/42 simplifies to 5/7 (÷6). List multiples of 6 and 8: 6, 12, 18, 24, 30... and 8, 16, 24, 32... LCM = 24. So to add 1/6 + 1/8, use 24 as common denominator.
stages.transition_cue: Child finds HCF and LCM on paper without arrays and uses them to simplify fractions and find common denominators

stages.description: Finding factors, common factors, HCF, multiples and LCM mentally, and applying them fluently to fraction operations
stages.example_activity: What is the HCF of 18 and 24? (6.) What is the LCM of 6 and 9? (18.) Simplify 24/36. Find a common denominator for 3/8 and 5/12. Is 7 a factor of 63?
stages.transition_cue: Child identifies HCF and LCM of any pair of numbers up to 100 within 5 seconds and applies them to fraction problems

stages.description: Using Dienes blocks to model the two partial products in long multiplication: partitioning the two-digit multiplier into tens and ones and building each product physically
stages.example_activity: Calculate 47 × 23. Build 47 × 3 with blocks: 141. Build 47 × 20 with blocks: 940. Combine: 141 + 940 = 1,081. Verify: the grid shows 40×20=800, 40×3=120, 7×20=140, 7×3=21. Total: 800+120+140+21=1,081.
stages.transition_cue: Child explains why long multiplication has two rows (ones product and tens product) and transitions to the written method without blocks

stages.description: Using the grid method side by side with the formal long multiplication layout, showing how the partial products correspond, then practising the compact method
stages.example_activity: Grid for 347 × 24: split into 300, 40, 7 across the top and 20, 4 down the side. Calculate all 6 cells. Total: 8,328. Now write the compact method: row 1 = 347 × 4 = 1,388. Row 2 = 347 × 20 = 6,940. Add: 8,328. Do they match?
stages.transition_cue: Child completes long multiplication using the compact method independently, correctly placing the zero placeholder and managing carries across both rows

stages.description: Performing long multiplication of up to 4-digit × 2-digit numbers fluently using the compact method, with estimation to check
stages.example_activity: Calculate 2,463 × 37. Estimate: 2,500 × 40 = 100,000. Calculate: 91,131. Is this plausible? Now try 4,085 × 26 (zero in the hundreds place).
stages.transition_cue: Child completes any long multiplication with correct carrying and zero handling, routinely estimating before calculating

stages.description: Using Dienes blocks and place value counters to model sharing (division) physically, demonstrating the bus stop method with concrete regrouping when a column does not divide evenly
stages.example_activity: Divide 852 ÷ 4. Build 852. Share 8 hundreds into 4 groups: 2 each. Share 5 tens into 4: 1 each with 1 ten remaining. Exchange that ten for 10 ones: now 12 ones. Share 12 into 4: 3 each. Answer: 213. Now try 865 ÷ 4: 1 one left over — remainder 1.
stages.transition_cue: Child models division with regrouping correctly with blocks and explains what happens when there is a remainder

stages.description: Recording short division using the bus stop layout on paper, showing the carried digits, and practising remainder interpretation with word problems
stages.example_activity: Write 3,024 ÷ 6 using bus stop layout. 3÷6=0 r3 (write 0, carry 3). 30÷6=5 (write 5). 2÷6=0 r2 (write 0, carry 2). 24÷6=4 (write 4). Answer: 504. Word problem: 43 children in groups of 5. 43÷5=8 r3. Need 9 groups. Why not 8?
stages.transition_cue: Child completes short division on paper with correct carrying (including zero quotients) and interprets remainders appropriately for the context

stages.description: Performing short division of up to 4-digit numbers by 1-digit divisors fluently, expressing remainders as whole numbers, fractions or decimals as context requires
stages.example_activity: Calculate 7,349 ÷ 8. Express the remainder as: (a) a whole number, (b) a fraction, (c) a decimal. A farmer has 2,350 eggs to pack in boxes of 6. How many full boxes? How many eggs left over?
stages.transition_cue: Child completes any short division fluently and selects the correct remainder form for the problem context without prompting

stages.description: Using fraction strips and fraction walls to physically demonstrate why a common denominator is needed, and overlaying strips to convert fractions to the same-sized pieces before combining
stages.example_activity: Add 1/3 + 1/4. Try putting a third-strip and a quarter-strip together — they don't line up on the wall. Convert both to twelfths: 1/3 = 4/12, 1/4 = 3/12. Now lay out 4 twelfth-strips + 3 twelfth-strips = 7 twelfths. So 1/3 + 1/4 = 7/12.
stages.transition_cue: Child explains why fractions need a common denominator before adding and finds the equivalent fractions using strips

stages.description: Drawing fraction bars to show conversion to a common denominator, recording the equivalent fraction steps on paper, and using LCM to find the most efficient denominator
stages.example_activity: Add 2/5 + 1/3. LCM of 5 and 3 = 15. Draw bars: 2/5 = 6/15, 1/3 = 5/15. Shade and combine: 11/15. Subtract 5/6 − 1/4. LCM of 6 and 4 = 12. 5/6 = 10/12, 1/4 = 3/12. 10/12 − 3/12 = 7/12. Simplify if possible.
stages.transition_cue: Child finds common denominators and adds/subtracts fractions on paper without fraction strips, simplifying the answer

stages.description: Adding and subtracting fractions with different denominators mentally or with minimal jottings, converting to mixed numbers when results exceed 1, and simplifying
stages.example_activity: Calculate 3/4 + 2/3. 5/6 − 1/4. 2/3 + 5/8. If 7/12 + ?/12 = 1, what is the missing fraction? Add 1 2/5 + 2 3/10.
stages.transition_cue: Child adds and subtracts fractions with different denominators fluently, converting improper fractions to mixed numbers and simplifying automatically

stages.description: Using fraction circles and fraction strips to build improper fractions beyond 1 whole and convert them to mixed numbers by grouping whole circles
stages.example_activity: Take 7 quarter-pieces. Make 1 whole circle (4 quarters) with 3 left over: 7/4 = 1 3/4. Now start with 2 1/3: that is 2 whole circles and 1 third-piece. Count all thirds: 6/3 + 1/3 = 7/3. Mark both 7/4 and 1 3/4 on the number line — same point.
stages.transition_cue: Child converts between improper fractions and mixed numbers using pieces, explaining the grouping process verbally

stages.description: Drawing fraction bars and number lines to show the conversion between improper fractions and mixed numbers, recording the division method on paper
stages.example_activity: Convert 13/5: draw a fraction bar split into fifths. Shade 13 sections: that fills 2 complete bars (10/5) with 3 left over. 13/5 = 2 3/5. Check by division: 13 ÷ 5 = 2 remainder 3, so 2 3/5. Convert 3 2/7 to improper: 3 × 7 + 2 = 23. So 23/7.
stages.transition_cue: Child converts in both directions on paper using the division/multiplication method without drawing fraction bars

stages.description: Converting between improper fractions and mixed numbers mentally, and using these conversions in fraction calculations
stages.example_activity: Convert 17/6 to a mixed number. Convert 4 3/8 to an improper fraction. Add 2 3/4 + 1 5/6 (convert to improper, find common denominator, add, convert back). Which is greater: 11/4 or 2 3/5?
stages.transition_cue: Child converts between forms instantly and uses these conversions fluently within fraction calculations

stages.description: Using a 10×10 hundredths grid to shade percentages, connecting to money (£1 = 100p) and fraction equivalences physically
stages.example_activity: Shade 35 squares of a hundredths grid: that is 35% = 35/100 = 0.35. Shade 50: that is 50% = 1/2 = 0.5. Use money: 25% of £1 = 25p = £0.25 = 1/4. Match cards: pair 20% with 1/5 and 0.2. What percentage is 3/4? Shade 75 squares.
stages.transition_cue: Child states the fraction and decimal equivalent of any common percentage (10%, 20%, 25%, 50%, 75%) without the grid

stages.description: Drawing bar models to find percentages of quantities, recording fraction-decimal-percentage conversion tables, and using number lines to show equivalences
stages.example_activity: Find 30% of 80 using a bar model: 10% = 8, so 30% = 24. Complete a conversion table: 1/5 = 0.2 = 20%, 3/10 = 0.3 = 30%, 1/8 = 0.125 = 12.5%. On a number line, mark 0%, 25%, 50%, 75%, 100% and label each with fraction and decimal equivalents.
stages.transition_cue: Child converts between fractions, decimals and percentages on paper and finds percentages of quantities using the bar model method

stages.description: Converting between fractions, decimals and percentages mentally, and finding percentages of quantities using efficient mental strategies
stages.example_activity: What is 35% as a decimal? As a fraction? Find 15% of 60 (10% = 6, 5% = 3, so 15% = 9). Convert 7/20 to a percentage. Which is more: 40% of 50 or 25% of 80?
stages.transition_cue: Child converts fluently between all three forms and calculates percentages of quantities mentally using benchmark strategies

stages.description: Using a large demonstration protractor on the board and individual pupil protractors to measure physical angles on shapes, turns and in the environment
stages.example_activity: Place the protractor on an angle card: centre on vertex, baseline on one arm, read the scale where the other arm crosses. This angle is 65° — it is acute. Measure the angles of a triangle cut-out: 50°, 60°, 70°. Do they sum to 180°? Draw an angle of 135° using the protractor.
stages.transition_cue: Child measures any angle accurately using a protractor, reading the correct scale, and estimates before measuring to verify

stages.description: Drawing and measuring angles on paper, recording measurements, and classifying angles as acute, right, obtuse, straight or reflex
stages.example_activity: Measure all angles in a quadrilateral diagram. Record: 95° (obtuse), 85° (acute), 110° (obtuse), 70° (acute). Sum: 360°. Draw angles of 45°, 90°, 120° and 200° (reflex: draw 360° − 200° = 160° and mark the reflex). Classify each angle.
stages.transition_cue: Child draws and measures any angle to within 2° accuracy, including reflex angles, and classifies all angle types

stages.description: Estimating angles before measuring, calculating reflex angles from acute/obtuse measurements, and applying angle measurement to problem-solving
stages.example_activity: Estimate the angle, then measure to check. If one angle on a straight line is 73°, what is the other? A reflex angle is 295°. What is the acute angle at the same point? The angles of a triangle are 48° and 67°. What is the third angle?
stages.transition_cue: Child estimates angles within 10° of the actual measurement and calculates missing angles using angle facts without measuring

stages.description: Tearing the corners off paper triangles and arranging them to make a straight line (180°), physically measuring angles at a point to verify they sum to 360°, and folding straight-line angles
stages.example_activity: Tear the 3 corners off a triangle. Arrange them point-to-point along a straight edge: they make a straight line = 180°. Draw 4 angles meeting at a point: measure each. Add: 90° + 120° + 85° + 65° = 360°. Fold a straight strip to create two angles: measure both. They sum to 180°.
stages.transition_cue: Child states the three angle facts (straight line = 180°, point = 360°, triangle = 180°) and applies them to find missing angles without measuring

stages.description: Drawing diagrams to show angle facts, labelling known and unknown angles, and writing equations to find missing angles
stages.example_activity: Draw a straight line with an angle of 125° on one side. The other angle = 180° − 125° = 55°. Label both. Draw a triangle with angles 40° and 75°. The third angle = 180° − 40° − 75° = 65°. Draw four angles at a point: three are 90°, 80° and 110°. The fourth = 360° − 280° = 80°.
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates missing angles using the correct angle fact, writing the equation and solving without needing to measure

stages.description: Applying angle facts to solve multi-step problems, combining facts about straight lines, points and triangles
stages.example_activity: Two angles on a straight line are equal. What is each? (90°.) A triangle has one angle of 90° and another of 35°. What is the third? An isosceles triangle has a base angle of 70°. What is the apex angle? Three of four angles at a point are 95°, 80° and 115°. Find the fourth.
stages.transition_cue: Child applies angle facts fluently in multi-step problems, selecting the correct fact and explaining their reasoning

stages.description: Using place value counters (0.001, 0.01, 0.1, 1) on a decimal place value mat and connecting to metric measurement: 1 mm = 0.001 m, 1 g = 0.001 kg
stages.example_activity: Build 2.345 on the mat: 2 ones, 3 tenths, 4 hundredths, 5 thousandths. Measure a pencil: 142 mm = 14.2 cm = 0.142 m. Weigh a coin: 7 g = 0.007 kg. What is the value of the 5 in 2.345? (5 thousandths = 0.005.)
stages.transition_cue: Child reads the value of any digit in a three-decimal-place number and connects thousandths to mm and g measurement contexts

stages.description: Using place value charts with three decimal columns, placing decimals on zoomed-in number lines, and comparing numbers with different numbers of decimal places
resources: number line templates (zoomed: 0.3 to 0.4 in thousandths)
stages.example_activity: Write 0.407 in a place value chart. Compare 0.407 and 0.47: chart shows 0.47 = 0.470, so 0.470 > 0.407. Place 0.345, 0.354 and 0.35 on a zoomed number line between 0.34 and 0.36. Order: 0.345, 0.35, 0.354.
stages.transition_cue: Child compares and orders decimals to three places without a chart, appending trailing zeros mentally to equalise decimal places

stages.description: Working with thousandths mentally: reading digit values, comparing and ordering, converting between fractions and decimals, and rounding to 1 or 2 decimal places
stages.example_activity: What is the value of the 6 in 4.836? Order: 0.5, 0.489, 0.51, 0.499. Convert 7/1000 to a decimal. Round 3.847 to 1 decimal place. What is 0.025 as a fraction?
stages.transition_cue: Child works with three-decimal-place numbers fluently, comparing, ordering, converting and rounding without visual aids

stages.description: Building cuboids from unit cubes (1 cm³), counting the cubes to find volume, and exploring how changing dimensions changes volume
stages.example_activity: Build a 3×4×2 cuboid from cubes. Count: 24 cubes = 24 cm³. Build a 5×2×3 cuboid: 30 cm³. Now double the height from 2 to 4 in the first cuboid: 3×4×4 = 48 cm³. The volume doubled. Build the biggest cuboid you can from 36 cubes.
stages.transition_cue: Child predicts the volume before building and explains: 'Volume = length × width × height because it is layers of rectangular arrays'

stages.description: Drawing cuboids on isometric paper with dimensions labelled, calculating volume using the formula, and distinguishing volume (cm³) from area (cm²)
stages.example_activity: Draw a cuboid 6 cm × 4 cm × 3 cm on isometric paper. Label the dimensions. Calculate: V = 6 × 4 × 3 = 72 cm³. What is the area of the base? 6 × 4 = 24 cm². How many layers of 24 cm² fit in the height? 3 layers = 72 cm³. Draw and calculate for a 5×5×5 cube.
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates volume from labelled diagrams using the formula and clearly distinguishes volume units (cm³) from area units (cm²)

stages.description: Calculating volumes of cuboids from given dimensions without drawing, solving problems involving volume, and working backwards from volume to find a missing dimension
stages.example_activity: A cuboid is 8 cm × 5 cm × 3 cm. What is its volume? A cube has volume 64 cm³. What is its edge length? A fish tank is 60 cm × 30 cm × 40 cm. How many litres of water does it hold? (1 litre = 1000 cm³.)
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates volumes mentally and works backwards from volume to find missing dimensions, connecting cm³ to litres

stages.description: Using mirrors on coordinate grids to reflect shapes, and physically sliding shape cut-outs to demonstrate translations, verifying that the shape stays the same size and shape
stages.example_activity: Place a triangle on the grid with vertices at (1,2), (3,2), (2,4). Put the mirror on the y-axis: the reflection appears at (-1,2), (-3,2), (-2,4). Trace the original and slide it 4 right, 3 down: new vertices (5,-1), (7,-1), (6,1). Check: the shape hasn't changed size.
stages.transition_cue: Child predicts the coordinates of reflected and translated vertices before checking with the mirror or tracing paper

stages.description: Drawing reflections and translations on coordinate grids, recording the new coordinates, and verifying congruence by comparing side lengths
stages.example_activity: Reflect the triangle (1,3), (4,3), (4,5) in the x-axis. Each point: (x, y) → (x, -y). New vertices: (1,-3), (4,-3), (4,-5). Draw both. Translate the shape (2,1), (5,1), (5,3), (2,3) by (-3, +2). New vertices: (-1,3), (2,3), (2,5), (-1,5). Check side lengths match.
stages.transition_cue: Child reflects in any horizontal or vertical line and translates by any vector, recording new coordinates without drawing first

stages.description: Predicting coordinates after reflections and translations mentally, combining transformations, and reasoning about which properties are preserved
stages.example_activity: A shape has vertices (2,3), (5,3), (5,6). Reflect in the y-axis, then translate 3 right. Where are the final vertices? What single transformation has the same effect? Does a reflection change the orientation of a shape? Does a translation?
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates transformed coordinates mentally and explains that translations preserve orientation while reflections reverse it

stages.description: Using Dienes blocks and place value counters on a five-column mat to add and subtract numbers with more than four digits, physically regrouping between columns
resources: Dienes blocks (ten-thousands, thousands, hundreds, tens, ones)
place value mat (TTh, Th, H, T, O)
stages.example_activity: Add 24,567 + 18,345. Build both numbers. Combine ones: 12 (exchange 10 for 1 ten). Combine tens: 12 (exchange 10 for 1 hundred). Continue through all columns. Total: 42,912. For subtraction: 30,004 − 17,658. Demonstrate cascading exchanges through the zeros.
stages.transition_cue: Child explains exchanges verbally and records columnar addition/subtraction on paper without blocks, including cascading through zeros

stages.description: Recording columnar addition and subtraction for large numbers on squared paper, using estimation to check, and developing mental strategies alongside written methods
stages.example_activity: Calculate 45,678 + 27,493 using column addition. Estimate first: 46,000 + 27,000 ≈ 73,000. Calculate: 73,171. Close to estimate? ✓. Mental strategy: 4,998 + 3,457. Adjust: 5,000 + 3,457 − 2 = 8,455. Which method was more efficient?
stages.transition_cue: Child selects the most efficient method (mental, jottings or written) for each calculation and explains their choice

stages.description: Performing addition and subtraction of large numbers fluently, selecting mental or written methods strategically, and solving multi-step word problems
stages.example_activity: Calculate 67,543 − 29,876. Use a mental strategy: 10,000 − 3,748 (adjust from 10,000). A school raised £24,750 in the autumn and £18,490 in the spring. How much altogether? How much more in autumn?
stages.transition_cue: Child solves multi-step problems with large numbers fluently, choosing the optimal strategy and checking with estimation

stages.description: Collecting real data and plotting it on large wall graphs, reading physical timetables (bus/train printed timetables), and calculating journey times using a clock
stages.example_activity: Plot the class temperature readings on a wall line graph. Read a bus timetable: the 9:15 bus from town centre arrives at the hospital at 9:42. How long is the journey? Use the clock to count: 27 minutes. What time does the next bus arrive?
stages.transition_cue: Child reads data from graphs and timetables, calculating journey times and comparing values without the demonstration clock

stages.description: Drawing line graphs with correct scales and labels, reading and interpolating values, and extracting information from printed tables and timetables on paper
stages.example_activity: Draw a line graph showing plant growth over 6 weeks. Use a scale of 2 cm per week on x-axis and 1 cm per 5 mm growth on y-axis. Estimate the height at week 3.5. From a train timetable, find the fastest train from London to Bristol and calculate the journey time.
stages.transition_cue: Child draws line graphs with appropriate scales, interpolates accurately, and solves comparison/difference problems from tables without prompting

stages.description: Interpreting graphs and timetables from descriptions, answering comparison/sum/difference questions, and choosing appropriate graph types for different data
stages.example_activity: A line graph shows temperature rising from 8°C at 6am to 22°C at 2pm, then falling to 14°C at 8pm. What was the temperature at 10am? How much did it fall between 2pm and 8pm? A timetable shows departures every 20 minutes from 7:00. What time is the 5th bus?
stages.transition_cue: Child interprets graphs and timetables from verbal descriptions, solves multi-step data questions, and justifies graph type choices
